Plant Species Classification Using Flower Images -- A Comparative Study of Local Feature Representations.
PLoS ONE 12(2): e0170629. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0170629
latestVersion.citationRequirements:
If you use this dataset, please cite:
Seeland M, Rzanny M, Alaqraa N, Wäldchen J, Mäder P.,
Plant Species Classification Using Flower Images -- A Comparative Study of Local Feature Representations.
PLoS ONE 12(2): e0170629. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0170629

dsDescriptionValue.value: Flower images of 30 wild-flowering angiosperm species found on semi-arid grasslands around the city of Jena in Germany. Classes are represented by 11 to 70 images with a total of 1,479 images. Class labels and definitions for training, validation and test splits for three folds are included as text files.

publicationCitation.value:
Plant species classification using flower images — A comparative study of local feature representations
M. Seeland, M. Rzanny, N. Alaqraa, J. Wäldchen, and P. Mäder

Description of Flower Colors for Image based Plant Species Classification
M. Seeland, M. Rzanny, N. Alaqraa, A. Thuille, J. Wäldchen, and P. Mäder

publicationIDNumber.value: @InProceedings{SeelandFWS2016,   author =       {Seeland, Marco AND Rzanny, Michael AND Alaqraa, Nedal AND Thuille, Angelika AND W{\"a}ldchen, Jana AND M{\"a}der, Patrick},   title =        {Description of Flower Colors for Image based Plant Species Classification},   booktitle =    {22. Workshop Farbbildverarbeitung 2016},   year =         {2016},   editor =       {K.-H. Franke AND R. Nestler},   pages =        {145--154},   organization = {German Color Group},   publisher =    {Zentrum für Bild- und Signalverarbeitung e.V.},   abstract =     {Apart from shape, color is the most visually prominent and perceivable feature of a flower. To use color as a feature for fine-grained plant species classification based on flower images, its descriptor has to be discriminative, compact, and robust against photometric variations. Therefore, we studied state-of-the-art color description methods and evaluated their discriminative power in an image classification pipeline. Experiments have been performed on three flower image datasets possessing large photometric and geometric varieties. We found that implicit photometric invariance by pooling 11 basic colors from patches around local features allows for robust color description outperforming explicitly photometric invariant descriptors in most cases.},   url =          {http://floraincognita.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/2016_FWS_mse_paper.pdf} }
